author: Jerit Roser, NOLA.com | The Times-Picayune
title: Leonard Fournette cuts twice as fast as the blink of an eye, per ESPN Sport Science
text:
Leonard Fournette's performance Saturday, despite being his season-low statistical output, was enough to catch the eye of ESPN's "Sport Science."
The LSU running back's rushing average actually slipped with his 158 yards in just two and a half quarters in Saturday's 45-24 romp past South Carolina.
The only Division I FBS running back averaging more yards than that output, the Tiger star's lowest of the season, thus far is Florida State's Dalvin Cook — and just barely, at 158.4 yards per game.
Fournette averaged 7.9 yards per carry against the Gamecocks, which would place him No. 6 in the country this season — except his season average is actually better (8.59).
And the science behind all the statistical success is equally ridiculous.
"One reason Fournette is able to dominate defenders is his elite agility," host John Brenkus said. "He consistently executed cuts in just two-tenths of a second — roughly twice as fast as the blink of an eye, and those cuts are as quick as cuts as we've measured from NFL All-Pro Adrian Peterson.
"To generate these explosive moves, Fournette pushes off the ground with an estimated four G's of acceleration. This allows him to maintain nearly 85 percent of his linear speed, even when he redirects his forward momentum by as much as 60 degrees. And perhaps Fournette's best skill is his ridiculous top-end speed. On his 87-yard TD run , he accelerated to over 20 miles an hour. That was fast enough to out-run the pursuing defensive backs Rico McWilliams and Al Harris Jr., even though Fournette outweighs each of them by at least 44 pounds."
